qas.question: Traditionally, what must a state do in order for an obligation to arise in international law?
What is the only barrier to withdrawal contained in many treaties?
Are treaties permanently binding upon the signatory parties?
What treaty will terminate if the number of parties falls below 40 as a result of denunciations?

answers.text: the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs

qas.question: Which article of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties provides that there is a presumption that treaties cannot be unilaterally denounced?

context: Treaties are <a2_0>not necessarily<a2_0/> permanently binding upon the signatory parties. As obligations in international law are traditionally viewed as arising only from the <a0_0>consent<a0_0/> of states, many treaties expressly allow a state to withdraw as long as it follows certain <a1_0>procedures of notification<a1_0/>. For example, <a3_0>the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs<a3_0/> provides that the treaty will terminate if, as a result of denunciations, the number of parties falls below 40. Many treaties expressly forbid withdrawal. <a4_0>Article 56<a4_0/> of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties provides that where a treaty is silent over whether or not it can be denounced there is a rebuttable presumption that it cannot be unilaterally denounced unless:
